taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013
IUCN Red List (Species Assessed for Global Conservation)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Despite being vulnerable to extinction, little is known about the Clanwilliam rock-catfish.  It feeds in on insects, especially the larvae of caddis and mayflies, and other small invertebrates taken from the bottom of the stream (3).  Catfishes from the Austroglanididae family are generally nocturnal (2) (5).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObjects.title: Description
dataObjects.description: The Clanwilliam rock-catfish, found only in a few streams in South Africa (4), belongs to the family of Austroglanididae catfishes, which are characterised by their scaleless, elongated bodies (5).  The Clanwilliam rock-catfish has a short dorsal fin, preceded by a strong spine, and a strong, serrated spine in the pectoral fins.  Four pairs of barbels (fleshy projections used to taste and feel), hang down near the mouth (6).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Occurs among rocks and cobbles and under banks in clear, flowing streams.  Feeds on insects, especially the larvae of caddis and mayflies, and other small invertebrates taken from the bottom (Ref. 7248).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Africa:  Clanwilliam-Olifants River system, South Africa.
dataObjects.references: Skelton, P.H. 1993 A complete guide to the freshwater fishes of southern Africa. Southern Book Publishers. 388 p. (Ref. 7248)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Clanwilliam-Olifants River system, South Africa, South Africa.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Range
dataObjects.description: The Clanwilliam catfish has been recorded from only 15 headwater streams of the Olifants River, in the Cedarberg Mountains, Western Cape Province, South Africa  (2) (3) (4).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: Habitat
dataObjects.description: Occurs among rocks and cobbles and under banks in clear, flowing streams (3).  Juveniles live in riffle habitats and then move into regions of deeper water as they mature (4).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObjects.title: Status
dataObjects.description: Classified as Vulnerable (VU) on the IUCN Red List 2007 (1).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObjects.title: Threats
dataObjects.description: The Olifants River system is one of the most heavily impacted in Africa (4).  The river system, and therefore the species which inhabit it, are under threat from human activities and infestation by alien species.  Damming, pesticide pollution, excessive extraction of water, the presence of alien fish such as bass, and infestation by invasive plants such as black wattle and blue gum have contributed to a dramatic decline in the quality of the riverine environment (7).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Management
dataObjects.title: Conservation
dataObjects.description: A two year project, funded by WWF South Africa, was undertaken in 1999 to gain further knowledge on the biology and population numbers of the Clanwilliam rock-catfish.  This resulted in a recommendation for the Clanwilliam rock-catfish to be classified as Endangered on the IUCN Red List.  A number of measures were also recommended to ensure the species survival; these include education of rural populations, protection of the streams, and removal of alien fishes and vegetation (4).  More recently, a Water Research Commission project has been looking at developing conservation action plans for three species within the Cedarberg region including the Clanwilliam rock-catfish (2).
